thread.title: 15 Helpful Things To Bring To Your Next Protest
thread.title_full: 15 Helpful Things To Bring To Your Next Protest

author: Nora Whelan
title: 15 Helpful Things To Bring To Your Next Protest
text:
View this image ›
Bryan R. Smith / AFP / Getty Images So, here are some items to bring along to help keep you (and others) safe and prepared.
ID: 10476556 1. A form of ID to prevent you from getting stuck. View this image ›
Sean Hobson / Via Flickr: seanhobson You very well may not be summonsed or arrested; however, if you are, having identification on you will likely save you time and hassle. Without documentation, cops can detain you until you’re positively identified.
ID: 10461017 2. A light layering jacket for unexpected temperature changes. View this image ›
store.americanapparel.net A soft hoodie will help keep you comfortable in the event of changing weather, or if you’re detained somewhere cold. This one from American Apparel (usually $48) is unisex, comes in a bunch of colors, and is 40% off while they clear their stock.
ID: 10461386 3. All the weather-appropriate accessories you usually skip. View this image ›
Zach Bonnell / Via Flickr: zachbonnell Even if you normally manage well enough without gloves and warm socks in winter, or a brimmed hat in the summer, chances are you’re probably not outdoors for as sustained a period of time as you would be during a public protest or march. Play it safe and make sure you’ve got the extras to shield you from whatever the season may bring.
ID: 10461374 4. Handheld snacks. View this image ›
Stef Noble / Via Flickr: stefnoble As with any time-consuming activity, you’ll want to make sure you keep your blood sugar stable for the duration. Energy bars are a great choice for both portability and hangry-ness prevention.
ID: 10474041 5. A permanent marker for important phone numbers. View this image ›
amazon.com Arrests do happen, so you’ll want to have the contact information of friends, family, and legal resources available — even if your belongings are confiscated. Write important numbers on your arm in permanent marker before heading out, and if you’re able, carry markers for anyone else who might need to do so during the demonstration.
ID: 10461259 6. Glasses to keep your eyes as safe as possible. View this image ›
Jenny Spadafora / Via Flickr: jspad Whether you wear regular eyeglasses or sunglasses doesn’t matter; what’s important is that you’re not wearing contacts , and that you have a barrier in front of your eyes — both will help you minimize damage should you come into contact with pepper spray.
ID: 10461343 7. A bottle of water to keep you refreshed. View this image ›
amazon.com In addition to keeping you hydrated, you might want water to help cool your skin or wash out your eyes ( some folks recommend whole milk for combating pepper spray; some don’t ). Whatever the case, it’s always good to have some H2O handy in a reusable bottle .
ID: 10475535 8. A portable phone charger. View this image ›
amazon.com Filming your fellow protestors without their consent is generally not cool; however, if you must film or make a phone call in the case of an emergency, you’ll want to be charged up. This portable battery works for a range of phones.
ID: 10475538 9. Oil-free sunscreen to protect your skin. View this image ›
amazon.com If you’re going to be outside in the daytime, you don’t want to risk sunburnt skin — and you definitely don’t want to get pepper-sprayed while wearing something oil-based , as it will be far more difficult to get the spray off your skin. Stay smart with oil-free sunscreen .
ID: 10461067 10. Something scarf-esque, for a few different reasons. View this image ›
amazon.com Wear a clean bandana to help obscure your features from surveillance (aside from mounted security cameras, how many people’s protest selfies have you unwittingly wound up in this month?); carry another soaked in lemon juice or apple cider vinegar to combat tear gas if it gets deployed.
ID: 10461258 11. First aid supplies. View this image ›
amazon.com You certainly don’t have to carry an entire kit, though this one is small enough that you could. Whatever the case, a mix of band-aids and gauze pads, wipes and antibiotic ointment, and NSAIDS should help with everything from sneaker-induced blisters to scuffle-induced scrapes.
ID: 10461260 12. Menstrual products. View this image ›
Matka_wariatka / Getty Images Support (your fellow?) menstruators! Pads are especially helpful for situations like arrests, in which you may not be able to change a tampon regularly enough , and tampons are as great for bloody noses as they are for their original intent.
ID: 10475761 13. Medication. View this image ›
Charles Williams / Via Flickr: charlesonflickr As with the reasoning behind pads, know that you may end up away from home longer than anticipated. For this reason, carry whatever pills, injections, inhalers, or anything else you need to stay in good health.
ID: 10461355 14. Cards to keep you informed of your rights. View this image ›
toasterdog.com Dealing with law enforcement can be disorienting, to say the least, but these cards from Lifehacker can help. Keep them handy with your cash and ID.
ID: 10461383 15. And a fanny pack to help you carry it all. View this image ›
amazon.com Maybe you don’t want to wear something as big as a backpack, and you definitely don’t want anything you have to carry in-hand or keep readjusting on your shoulder. Enter: the fanny pack , preferably with multiple pockets to keep you organized.
ID: 10461357 Now, go show ‘em what democracy looks like. View this image ›
